Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Since CO2 stayed more or less constant over this time scale, so did temperature.
CO2: The decrease in buried carbon lowers one of atmospheric carbon's sinks.  Carbon sources (which remain constant in this scenario) exceed carbon removal, causing an increase.  It will take longer than 200 years to cause a level change though.
Volcano: Volcanoes, mountain level, and weathering of buried carbon stay the same throughout this scenario.
Ice: Because temperature remained nearly constant, ice levels did to.
Sea: Because temperature (and ice level) remained fairly constant, so did sea level, weathering, and carbonate deposition.
Sediment: This scenario assumes carbon burial by sediments decreases.  It starts at a moderately high level (4).  It decreases to level 3 to start the process.

Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Because CO2 rose, so did temperature.
CO2: Because C sources (constant) exceed C sinks, atmospheric carbon increased.
Ice: Temperature rise melts polar ice, lowering the planet's ice level.
Sea: Because temperature (and ice level) rose, so did sea level.
Weathering C Burial: Because temperature rose, the planet experiences more rain, increasing the weathering rate.
CO3 Desposition: Higher weathering rate washes more Ca and C to sea, increasing carbonate deposition rate, increasing the C sinks, although not enough to move system back to equilibrium.
Sediment: By 100,000 years, carbon burial has decreased from its initial level of 4 to 2.

Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Because CO2 rose, so did temperature.
CO2: Because C sources (constant) still exceed C sinks, atmospheric carbon increased.
Ice: Temperature rise melts polar ice, lowering the planet's ice level.
Sea: Because temperature rose and ice level dropped, so did sea level.
Weathering C Burial: Because temperature rose, the planet experiences more rain, increasing the weathering rate.
CO3 Desposition: Higher weathering rate washes more Ca and C to sea, increasing carbonate deposition rate, increasing the C sinks, although not enough to move system back to equilibrium.
Sediment: Organic carbon burial drops to level 1 (the forcer).

Temperature: Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.  Because CO2 rose, so did temperature.
CO2: Because C sources (constant) still exceed C sinks, atmospheric carbon increased.  It comes to equilibruim due to the response of carbonate deposition.
Ice: Temperature rise melts the remainder of the polar ice.
Sea: Because temperature rose and ice level dropped, so did sea level.
Weathering C Burial: Because temperature rose, the planet experiences more rain, increasing the weathering rate.
CO3 Desposition: Higher weathering rate washes more Ca and C to sea, increasing carbonate deposition rate, increasing the C sinks, although not enough to move system back to equilibrium.
Sediment: Organic carbon burial remains at level 1 (the forcer).
